fieldInfos.label: Percent green space along walkable roads

layer.name: Percent green space along walkable roads
layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset estimates green space along walkable roads. Green space within 25 meters of the road centerline is included and the percentage is based on the total area between street intersections. Green space provides valuable benefits to neighborhood residents and walkers by providing shade, improved aesthetics, and outdoor gathering spaces.

fieldInfos.label: Percent green space within 1/4 square kilometer

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of total land within each ¼ square kilometer that is covered by vegetation, or “green space.”  Green space may include trees, lawns and gardens, crop land, and forested wetlands.
layer.name: Percent green space within 1/4 square kilometer

fieldInfos.label: Percent impervious area within 1 square kilometer

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of each square kilometer within the community area that is covered by impervious surfaces. It is not summarized by census block group. Impervious surfaces are materials that do not allow the penetration of water and include buildings, roads, and sidewalks.

fieldInfos.label: Percent tree cover along walkable roads

layer.name: Percent tree cover along walkable roads
layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset estimates tree cover along walkable roads. The road width is estimated for each road and percent tree cover is calculated in a 8.5 meter strip beginning at the estimated road edge. Percent tree cover is calculated for each block between road intersections. Tree cover provides valuable benefits to neighborhood residents and walkers by providing shade, improved aesthetics, and outdoor gathering spaces.

layer.name: Acres of land enrolled in CRP

fieldInfos.label: Acres of land enrolled in CRP

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the acres of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that are enrolled in the US Department of Agriculture's Conservation Reserve Program (CRP). The CRP is a program administered by the Farm Service Agency; farmers in the program receive annual payments and establishment cost share to remove environmentally sensitive land from crop production and instead plant perennial species that provide environmental benefits.

fieldInfos.label: Acres of pollinated crops with no nearby pollinator habitat

layer.eaDescription: This map layer depicts the total acres of agricultural crops within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that require or would benefit from the presence of pollinators, but are without any nearby supporting habitat for 2006-2010.
layer.name: Acres of pollinated crops with no nearby pollinator habitat

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the millions of gallons of water used daily for agricultural irrigation for each subwatershed (HUC-12) in the contiguous United States for 2001-2010. Estimates include self-supplied surface and groundwater, as well as water supplied by irrigation water providers, which may include governments, companies, or other organizations.
layer.name: Agricultural water use (million gallons/day)

fieldInfos.label: Percent agriculture in areas of high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and is managed for agriculture for 2006-2010. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet.
layer.name: Percent agriculture in areas of high water accumulation
Percent agriculture on hydric soil
layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the percentage of land managed for agriculture that has hydric soils within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2006-2010. This includes all land dedicated to the production of crops, but excludes land managed for pasture.

This map depicts the percent of land managed as cropland in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. For this map, EnviroAtlas uses all crop types in the Cropland Data Layer created by the United States Department of Agriculture.
layer.name: Percent cropland
Percent developed area
layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the amount of developed land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. For the purposes of this map, developed land cover includes a variety of development, such as single family homes, multifamily housing units, retail, commercial, industrial sites, and associated infrastructure. Developed land cover is not confined to city limits.

fieldInfos.label: Percent developed land in areas of high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and has been developed or urbanized for 2006-2010. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet. This map includes various types of development such as open spaces, parks, golf courses, single family homes, multifamily housing units, retail, commercial, industrial sites, and associated infrastructure.
layer.name: Percent developed land in areas of high water accumulation
Percent emergent herbaceous wetlands
layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the percent of land comprised of emergent herbaceous wetlands in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. For this map, EnviroAtlas uses the National Land Cover Database and its definition of  emergent herbaceous wetlands.

layer.name: Percent forest
layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percentage of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forest for 2011.

layer.name: Percent forest and woody wetlands
layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percentage of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forest or woody wetlands for 2011. EnviroAtlas uses the National Land Cover Database definition of woody wetlands.

layer.name: Percent forest and woody wetlands in stream buffer

fieldInfos.label: Percent forest and woody wetlands in stream buffer

layer.eaDescription: This map layer portrays the percent of land within 30 meters of streams, rivers, and other hydrologically connected waterbodies within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forests or woody wetlands for 2006. EnviroAtlas uses the 2006 National Land Cover Database definition of woody wetlands.

fieldInfos.label: Percent forest in areas with high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and is covered by trees and forests for 2006-2010. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet.
layer.name: Percent forest in areas with high water accumulation
Percent forest land in stream buffer

fieldInfos.label: Percent forest land in stream buffer

layer.eaDescription: This map layer portrays the percent of land within 30 meters of streams, rivers, and other hydrologically connected waterbodies within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is covered by trees and forests for 2006.

This map illustrates the percent of land within subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has legally recognized easements for conservation or other protections in place to restrict human use or development for 2011. This layer includes both public and private land.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 1 and 2

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has legally recognized easements for conservation or other protections in place to restrict human use or development for 2011. This layer includes both public and private land.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 1, 2, and 3

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is designated as Status 3 under the USGS Gap Analysis Program for 2011. These areas have permanent protection from conversion of natural land cover for the majority of area. Subject to extractive uses of either broad, low-intensity type (e.g.. Logging) or localized intense type (e.g.. Mining). Confers protection to federally listed endangered and threatened species throughout the area.
layer.name: Percent GAP status 3
Percent impervious area
layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is impervious for 2006. Impervious surfaces do not allow the penetration of water and include buildings, roads, and sidewalks.

This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IA by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IA protected areas seek to protect biodiversity and natural features; human visitation, use, and impacts are strictly controlled.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IA

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IB by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IB protected areas include large unmodified or slightly modified areas, without permanent or significant human habitation. These lands are protected and managed so as to protect their natural condition.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IB

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status II by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category II protected areas re large natural or near natural areas set aside to protect large-scale ecological processes, along with the complement of species and ecosystems characteristic of the area, which also provide a foundation for environmentally and culturally compatible, spiritual, scientific, educational, recreational, and visitor opportunities.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status II

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status III by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category III protected areas are set aside to protect a specific natural monument, which can be a landform, sea mount, submarine cavern, geological feature such as a cave or even a living feature such as an ancient grove. They are generally quite small protected areas and often have high visitor value.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status III

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IV by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IV areas aim to protect particular species or habitats and management reflects this priority. Many Category IV protected areas will need regular, active interventions to address the requirements of particular species or to maintain habitats, but this is not a requirement of the category.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status IV

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status V by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category V protected areas have distinct character with significant, ecological, biological, cultural and scenic value: and where safeguarding the integrity of this interaction is vital to protecting and sustaining the area and its associated nature conservation and other values.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status V

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status VI by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category VI protected areas are generally large, with most of the area in a natural condition, where a proportion is under sustainable natural resource management and where low-level non-industrial use of natural resources compatible with nature conservation is seen as one of the main aims of the area.
layer.name: Percent IUCN status VI

fieldInfos.label: Percent land with any IUCN status

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is protected. It includes all lands that have been classified by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) as protected areas for 2011.
layer.name: Percent land with any IUCN status

fieldInfos.label: Percent large size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by large patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Large natural areas are greater than 25,000 acres and covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.
layer.name: Percent large size patches of natural land cover

fieldInfos.label: Percent medium size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by medium sized patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Medium natural areas are less 25,000 acres but greater than 500 acres and are covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.
layer.name: Percent medium size patches of natural land cover
Percent natural land cover
layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of total land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has natural land cover for 2011. Natural land cover includes forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, and wetlands; it excludes agriculture and impervious surfaces.

fieldInfos.label: Percent natural land cover in stream buffer

layer.name: Percent natural land cover in stream buffer
layer.eaDescription: This map layer portrays the percent of naturally covered land within 30 meters of streams, rivers, and other hydrologically connected waterbodies within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2006. Natural land cover includes forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, and wetlands; it excludes agriculture and developed land.

fieldInfos.label: Percent of rare ecosystem forms protected

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that could be classified as rare ecosystem forms that is protected for 2011. Ecosystem rarity in EnviroAtlas is based on size, shape, and type of ecosystem.
layer.name: Percent of rare ecosystem forms protected
Percent of stream and shoreline with 15% or more impervious cover within 30 meters

fieldInfos.label: Percent of stream and shoreline with 15% or more impervious cover within 30 meters

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of stream and water body shoreline lengths that had impervious cover greater than or equal to 15% within 30 meters for 2011.

layer.name: Percent of stream and shoreline with 5% or more impervious cover within 30 meters

fieldInfos.label: Percent of stream and shoreline with 5% or more impervious cover within 30 meters

layer.eaDescription: Percentage of stream and water body shoreline lengths that had impervious cover greater than or equal to 5% within 30 meters for 2011.

layer.name: Percent pasture
layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the percent of land managed as pasture in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. Pasture areas are planted for livestock grazing or the production of seed or hay crops.

fieldInfos.label: Percent potentially restorable wetlands on agricultural land

layer.name: Percent potentially restorable wetlands on agricultural land
layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that may be suitable for wetland restoration and is on agricultural land for 2011.

layer.name: Percent range in areas with high water accumulation

fieldInfos.label: Percent range in areas with high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and is covered by range land for 2006-2010. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet. EnviroAtlas defines range as land dominated by shrubs or herbaceous vegetation.

This map estimates the percent of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that could be classified as rare ecosystem forms for 2011. Ecosystem rarity in EnviroAtlas is based on size, shape, and type of ecosystem.
layer.name: Percent rare ecosystem forms

fieldInfos.label: Percent small size patches of natural land cover

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the percent of land within each subwatershed that is covered by small patches of natural areas for 2006-2010. Small natural areas are less 500 acres and covered by forests, shrubs, grasslands, barren land, or wetlands. It excludes areas that are covered by agriculture and developed land.
layer.name: Percent small size patches of natural land cover
Percent wetlands
layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the percent of land comprised of woody and emergent herbaceous wetlands in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. For this map, EnviroAtlas uses the National Land Cover Database and its definitions of woody and emergent herbaceous wetlands.

fieldInfos.label: Percent wetlands in areas with high water accumulation

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the percent of land within a subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is frequently or periodically wet due to high water accumulation and is covered by wetlands for 2006-2010. This map uses a wetness index of 550 from a compound topographic index (CTI) to determine if the area is considered to be wet. EnviroAtlas uses the National Land Cover Database classification of wetlands.
layer.name: Percent wetlands in areas with high water accumulation

fieldInfos.label: Population near roadway with little to no tree buffer

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the total population that lives within 90 meters of a major road with little to no tree buffer for 2006. For the purposes of this map, little to no tree buffer means that no area within the 90 meters was classified in the National Land Cover Database as forest.
layer.name: Population near roadway with little to no tree buffer
Stream density (km/km2)
layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the drainage density within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2015-2016. The density is equal to the total stream length in kilometers within a subwatershed divided by its total area in square kilometers.

layer.name: Stream length (km)
layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the total kilometers of streams, rivers, or other linear waterways within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2015-2016. It includes both natural and man-made water features, but excludes non-linear waterbodies such as lakes.
This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by mercury for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by mercury (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by metals other than mercury (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired due to the presence of metals other than mercury in the water for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by metals other than mercury (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by nuisance species (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by algal growth, noxious aquatic plants, and nuisance native or invasive plants, animals, fish, or microbes for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by nuisance species (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired due to the presence of nutrients in the water for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by nutrients (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by organic enrichment or oxygen depletion (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by excessive organic materials or reduced oxygen for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by organic enrichment or oxygen depletion (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by microbes, such as bacteria, that can spread disease for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by pathogens (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by pesticides, such as herbicide and insecticide for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by pesticides (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by pH, acidity, or caustic conditions (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired due to being too acidic or too alkaline for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by pH, acidity, or caustic conditions (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length impaired by sediment or turbidity (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired by sediment or turbidity for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired by sediment or turbidity (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired for having higher than average temperature for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length impaired for temperature (km)

fieldInfos.label: Stream length with any other impairment (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired due to any other cause, including flow alterations, habitat alterations, ammonia, biotoxins, chlorine, dioxins, oil and grease, PCBs, radiation, salinity, toxic substances, trash, taste, color, or odor for 2015-2016.
layer.name: Stream length with any other impairment (km)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the total stream length in kilometers within the subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been listed as impaired for biota, including fish kills and fish consumption advisory for 2015-2016. Biota or biological impairment is an indication of water quality and not the source of impairment.
layer.name: Stream length with impaired biota (km)
Synthetic nitrogen fertilizer application (kg N/ha/yr)
layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the mean rate of synthetic nitrogen fertilizer application to agricultural lands within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kg N/ha/yr for 2006.

This map estimates the millions of gallons of water used daily for thermoelectric power generation in each subwatershed (HUC-12) for 2009. Thermoelectric power creates electricity through steam powered turbines. This map is based on water withdrawn and does not include water that is returned to the watershed.
layer.name: Thermoelectric water use (million gallons/day)
Total annual nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)
layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the total annual deposition of nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. This map includes both dry and wet deposition of oxidized and reduced nitrogen.

layer.name: Total annual oxidized nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)
layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the annual  deposition of oxidized nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. This map includes both dry and wet deposition of oxidized nitrogen.

layer.name: Total annual reduced nitrogen deposition (kg/ha)
layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the annual deposition of reduced nitrogen within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. This map includes both dry and wet deposition of reduced nitrogen.

layer.name: Total annual sulfur deposition (kg/ha)
layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the annual deposition of sulfur within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) in kilograms per hectare for 2011. This map includes both dry and wet deposition of sulfur.

layer.name: Total number of at-risk aquatic species

fieldInfos.label: Total number of at-risk aquatic species

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the total number of species associated with aquatic habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011.

fieldInfos.label: Total number of at-risk terrestrial species

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the total number of species associated with terrestrial habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. G1 and G2 denote Global Conservation Ranks classified by NatureServe. Terrestrial habitat refers to land areas such as forests, grasslands, deserts and rainforests.
layer.name: Total number of at-risk terrestrial species
Total number of at-risk wetland species

fieldInfos.label: Total number of at-risk wetland species

layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates the total number of species associated with wetland habitat that are listed as G1, G2, or in the federal endangered species program that may reside within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2011. G1 and G2 denote Global Conservation Ranks classified by NatureServe.
This map depicts annual sales in dollars for cotton produced within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2007-2010.
layer.name: Value of cotton crops (dollars/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts annual sales in dollars for major grain crops produced within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2007-2010.
layer.name: Value of grain crops (dollars/yr)

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts the thousands of tons of vegetable crops that are grown annually within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) for 2010.
layer.name: Vegetable yields (thousand tons/yr)

fieldInfos.label: Water supply from NID reservoirs (million gallons)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the millions of gallons of surface water in each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that is contained in the 2009 National Inventory of Dams reservoirs and/or behind dams. This map only estimates volume and does not take into account water rights, designated uses, or previous appropriations.
layer.name: Water supply from NID reservoirs (million gallons)

layer.eaDescription: This map estimates the total square kilometers of lakes, ponds, reservoirs, estuaries, playas, swamps, and marshes within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC).
layer.name: Waterbody area (km2)
Potential Wetland Area
layer.eaDescription: The EnviroAtlas Potential Wetland Areas (PWA) dataset shows potential wetland areas at 30-meter resolution. Beginning two centuries ago, many wetlands were turned into farm fields or urban areas, yet wetlands play an important role in removing water pollution, regulating water storage and flows, and providing habitat for wildlife. Wetland restoration could help restore these benefits. Potential wetland areas, as developed for this map, are lands that naturally accumulate water due to topography and have historically had poorly or very poorly draining soils. This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to the EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).

fieldInfos.label: Potentially Restorable Wetlands on Agricultural Land

layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset shows potentially restorable wetlands at 30 meter resolution. Potentially restorable wetlands for this map are lands currently in agriculture that naturally accumulate water and historically had poor drainage and hydric soils.
layer.name: Potentially Restorable Wetlands on Agricultural Land

layer.eaDescription: This map for rare ecosystems in the conterminous U.S. delineates the Relative Rarity Metric developed by the EPA. The metric is based on current extent, spatial pattern type, and relative uniqueness. Metric values range from 0 to 100 with higher values indicating greater relative ecosystem rarity.
layer.name: Rare Ecosystems

eaTags: International Union for Conservation of Nature
layer.name: IUCN Category (Land Protection Status (IUCN))
Land_Cover_2011_CONUS (NLCD_2011, National Land Cover Database (NLCD))
layer.eaDescription: NLCD (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 2011 is a 16-class land cover classification scheme that has been applied consistently across the conterminous U.S. at a spatial resolution of 30 meters.For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.

layer.name: Land_Cover_1992 (NLCD_1992, National Land Cover Database (NLCD))
layer.eaDescription: NLCD (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 1992 is a 21-class land cover classification scheme that has been applied consistently across the conterminous U.S. at a spatial resolution of 30 meters. For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.

layer.name: Land_Cover_2001_CONUS (NLCD_2001, National Land Cover Database (NLCD))
layer.eaDescription: NLCD  (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 2001 is a 16-class land cover classification scheme that also has been applied to the conterminous U.S. at a spatial resolution of 30 meters, and includes Alaska, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico. For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.

layer.name: Land_Cover_2006_CONUS (NLCD_2006, National Land Cover Database (NLCD))
layer.eaDescription: NLCD (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 2006 is a 16-class scheme that quantifies land cover change for the conterminous U.S. between the years 2001 to 2006. Generation of NLCD 2006 helped identify and correct issues in the NLCD 2001 land cover and impervious surface products only and no changes were made to the NLCD 2001 canopy product. For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.

layer.name: Soils Drainage Class - dominant condition
layer.eaDescription: This category contains a map of a variable from the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's soils dataset, called SSURGO (Soil Survey Geographic Database), that contains all variables found in county soil surveys. The SSURGO variable natural drainage class (dominant condition) was selected for use in EnviroAtlas because it indicates soil wetness or degree of saturation.

layer.name: USEPA Ecoregions (Omernik) - Level IV
layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates USEPA (Omernik) Level III and IV ecoregions, a geographic framework used for an ecosystem approach to land and water resource management. Ecoregions define relatively homogeneous geographical areas that contain similarities in the character of environmental resources.

layer.name: USEPA Ecoregions (Omernik) - Level III
layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates USEPA (Omernik) Level III and IV ecoregions, a geographic framework used for an ecosystem approach to land and water resource management. Ecoregions define relatively homogeneous geographical areas that contain similarities in the character of environmental resources.

The GAP (Gap Anlaysis Program) Ecological Systems data layer, one of several data layers available in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) GAP Land Cover Dataset, depicts native vegetation, agricultural areas, and urban development in 590 land use classes. Ecological Systems refers to the vegetation classification developed by NatureServe to map the natural vegetation of the U.S. Separate Ecological Systems datasets have been created for Alaska (LANDFIRE) and Hawaii (Hawaii Gap Analysis Project).
layer.name: GAP Ecological Systems

layer.eaDescription: These maps identify waterbodies that have been assessed and determined to be impaired, meaning that the waterbody has been degraded and does not meet the standards for seven designated beneficial uses (such as aquatic life habitat, drinking water supply, and fish consumption). This map identifies area features from the Impaired Waters database.
layer.name: Impaired Waters

layer.eaDescription: This map depicts waterbodies that have been assessed by states, territories, and authorized tribes every two years to evaluate waterbody condition for seven beneficial uses (such as aquatic life habitat, drinking water supply, and fish consumption). Those waterbodies not meeting the standards for beneficial uses are designated as impaired or threatened. This map identifies area features from the Assessed Waters database.
layer.name: Assessed Waters

layer.eaDescription: This National Wetlands Inventory (NWI) map, developed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, maps and classifies wetlands across the U.S. State and local government agencies use NWI in planning to identify local wetlands and to limit and mitigate wetland losses during economic development.
layer.name: Wetlands

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of project footprints or project primary impact areas in which watershed ecosystem service projects operate per Ecosystem Marketplace research.
layer.name: Watersheds - Projects [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of market coverage areas in which watershed ecosystem service markets operate per Ecosystem Marketplace research. National-level markets are an exception to this norm with points representing administrative headquarters locations.
layer.name: Watersheds - Markets [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent the HUC8 watersheds that primary impact areas of watershed projects correspond with or exist within per Ecosystem Marketplace research. The standard geographic units for depicting watershed projects are HUC8 watersheds. There are no watershed projects identified as being larger than “local” per the above definition at this time
layer.name: Watersheds - Projects [boundaries]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent the HUC8 watersheds that market coverage areas of local watershed markets correspond with or exist within per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Watershed markets are identified as local if their market coverage areas encompass two or fewer HUC8 watersheds. The exception to this rule is the Deschutes Groundwater Mitigation Program, whose coverage encompasses greater than two HUC8 watersheds but is considered to be local in this dataset. The standard geographic units for depicting local watershed markets are HUC8 watersheds.
layer.name: Watersheds - Local-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent watershed market coverage areas associated with watershed markets operating at a scale encompassing multiple states, counties, and/or a minimum of three HUC8 watersheds according to Ecosystem Marketplace research. Data were derived from disparate sources and merged into a single shapefile. There are no identified regional-level projects at this time.
layer.name: Watersheds - Regional-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent watershed market coverage areas whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified state-level watershed projects at this time
layer.name: Watersheds - State-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with watershed markets operating at a national scale per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified national watershed projects at this time.
layer.name: Watersheds - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of project footprints or project primary impact areas in which imperiled species and/or habitat ecosystem service projects operate. Credit bank point data and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional imperiled species and/or habitat project point data generated from Ecosystem Marketplace research were merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitats - Projects [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of market coverage areas in which imperiled species and/or habitat ecosystem service markets operate per Ecosystem Marketplace research. National-level markets are an exception to this norm with points representing administrative headquarters locations.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitats - Markets [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent project footprints and project primary impact areas associated with imperiled species and/or habitat projects. Credit bank project footprints and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional imperiled species and/or habitat project polygons generated from Ecosystem Marketplace were drawn corresponding with the HUC8 boundaries in which projects operate and merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitats - Projects [boundaries]

fieldInfos.label: Imperiled Species and Habitats - Regional-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with regional imperiled species and/or habitat markets operating at a scale encompassing multiple states or the majority of a state’s geographic area per ecosystem marketplace research. There are no identified local imperiled species and/or habitat markets identified at this time.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitats - Regional-scale Markets

fieldInfos.label: Imperiled Species and Habitats - State-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent imperiled species and/or habitat market coverage areas whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified state-level imperiled species and/or habitat projects at this time.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitats - State-scale Markets

fieldInfos.label: Imperiled Species and Habitats - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with imperiled species and/or habitat markets operating at a national scale per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified national imperiled species and/or habitat projects at this time.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitats - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of project footprints or project primary impact areas in which wetland and stream ecosystem service projects operate. Credit bank point data and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional wetland and stream project point data generated from Ecosystem Marketplace research were merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - Projects [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of market coverage areas in which wetland and stream ecosystem service markets operate. National-level markets are an exception to this norm with points representing administrative headquarters locations. In-lieu fee program point data and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional wetland and stream market point data generated from Ecosystem Marketplace research were merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - Markets [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent project footprints and project primary impact areas associated with wetland and stream projects. Credit bank project footprints and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional wetland and stream project polygons generated from Ecosystem Marketplace were drawn corresponding with the HUC8 boundaries in which projects operate and merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - Projects [boundaries]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with regional wetland and stream markets operating at a scale encompassing multiple states or the majority of a state’s geographic areas. In-lieu fee program polygon data and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional wetland and stream market point data generated from Ecosystem Marketplace research were merged with RIBITS data. There are no identified local wetland and stream markets identified at this time.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - Regional-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent wetland and stream market coverage areas whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified state-level wetland and stream projects at this time.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - State-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with wetland and stream markets operating at a national scale per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified national wetland and stream projects at this time.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the locations of forest carbon ecosystem service projects. Point data were sourced from pre-existing lat/lon coordinates of forest carbon project locations compiled through Ecosystem Marketplace research.
layer.name: Forest Carbon - Projects [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of market coverage areas associated with forest carbon markets per Ecosystem Marketplace research. National-level markets are an exception to this norm with points representing administrative headquarters locations.
layer.name: Forest Carbon - Markets [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent forest carbon market coverage areas whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified state-level forest carbon projects at this time.
layer.name: Forest Carbon - State-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent forest carbon market coverage areas associated with forest carbon markets operating at a national scale per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified national forest carbon projects at this time.
layer.name: Forest Carbon - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent HUC8 watersheds in which a watershed-level enabling condition is implemented. Watershed-level enabling conditions are those whose boundaries correspond with or exist within two or fewer HUC8 watersheds. The exception to this is the collection of Deschutes Basin Ground Water Mitigation Rules, whose coverage encompasses greater than two HUC8 watersheds but is considered to be local, or watershed-level, in this dataset. Identified watershed-level enabling conditions apply only for watershed ecosystem service initiatives at this time.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - Watershed-scale

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent enabling conditions whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Identified state-level enabling conditions apply for watershed, Imperiled Species and Habitats, wetland and streams, and forest carbon asset types.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - State-scale

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent enabling conditions whose boundaries encompass: a) for imperiled species/habitat, wetland/stream, and forest carbon asset types, at least the majority of a state’s geographic area; b) for watershed asset types, a minimum of three HUC8 watersheds. Identified regional-level enabling conditions apply only for watershed ecosystem service initiatives at this time.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - Regional-scale

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent enabling conditions whose boundaries correspond with federal lands boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Identified federal lands-level enabling conditions apply only for watershed and imperiled species/habitat ecosystem service initiatives at this time.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - Federal lands-scale

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent enabling conditions whose boundaries correspond with the U.S. national boundary per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Identified national-level enabling conditions apply for watershed, Imperiled Species and Habitats, and wetland and stream ecosystem service initiatives at this time.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - National-scale
USEPA Ecoregions (Omernik) -Level III
layer.eaDescription: This map illustrates USEPA (Omernik) Level III and IV ecoregions, a geographic framework used for an ecosystem approach to land and water resource management. Ecoregions define relatively homogeneous geographical areas that contain similarities in the character of environmental resources.

fieldInfos.label: MSPA connectivity with water as background and 30-meter edge width for the conterminous United States

layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset categorizes land cover into structural elements such as core, edge, or connector. Water is treated as background in this dataset, and edges have a width of 1 pixel (30 meters).
layer.name: MSPA connectivity with water as background and 30-meter edge width for the conterminous United States

layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset categorizes land cover into structural elements such as core, edge, or connector. Water is treated as background in this dataset, and edges have a width of 3 pixels (90 meters).
layer.name: test_services/MSPA2011_WB_8311
